newsitem.title: ZAMBIA: Zambian police arrest rioting university students.
newsitem.headline: Zambian police arrest rioting university students.

text.p: Zambian police arrested 10 students after using teargas and batons to break up riots at the University of Zambia on Monday, the campus administration said.
Zambia's biggest university also expelled nine students and suspended another after two days of rioting, during which protesters vandalised the university campus and stoned vehicles.

"In line with management's firm resolve to bring an end to all acts in indiscipline in the university, nine students have been expelled with immediate effect. A tenth student has been expelled for one academic year," the university administration said in a statement.
The street rampages started on Sunday night. Riot police were sent to the campus on Monday and fought pitched battles with scores of stone-throwing students, finally driving them back with teargas.
University spokesman Mulife Malambo told Reuters students were unhappy over delays in the disbursement of book allowances.

"We have told the students that the university is not responsible for their allowances. The government is," Malambo said. "However, the students have decided to call for a class boycott and the normal schedule has been disrupted," he added.
Last November the university was closed for several weeks due to student riots sparked by a protests against the way general elections, boycotted by seven opposition parties, had been organised.
President Frederick Chiluba's Movement for Multi-party Democracy won the November election, but the poll results were dismissed by international observers as flawed.
Students at Zambia's second university on Monday urged the government to pay meal and food allowances which they said were two weeks overdue.
"Students are starving and their morale to go to classes is very low. Government should immediately pay us the money," said a student leader at the Copperbelt University.
